description: {"blocks":[{"key":"beast","text":"Circular RNA (circRNA) is a noncoding RNA class with broad implications for gene expression regulation, mostly by e.g. interaction with other RNAs or RNA-binding proteins. However, their specific sequence is not revealed by the commonly applied short-read Illumina sequencing. Here, we present an adapted protocol to enrich and sequence full-length circRNAs using the Oxford Nanopore long-read sequencing platform. The protocol involves an RNaseH-based ribodepletion, an enrichment of lowly abundant circRNAs by exonuclease treatment and negative selection of linear RNAs. Then, a cDNA library is created and amplified by PCR. This library is used as input for ligation-based sequencing together with native barcoding. Stringent quality control of the libraries is ensured by a combination of Qubit, Fragment Analyzer and qRT-PCR. The recommended amount of starting material is 7 µg of RNA, however lower amounts of RNA have also been tested successfully. Multiplexing of up to 4 libraries yields in total more than 1-2 Mio reads per library, of which 1-2 % are circRNA-specific reads with \u003e99 % of them full-length. The protocol works well with human cancer cell lines. We further provide suggestions for Nanopore sequencing, the bioinformatic analysis of the created data, as well as the limitations of our approach and recommendations for troubleshooting and results interpretation. Taken together, this protocol enables reliable full-length analysis of circRNAs, a non-coding RNA type involved in a growing number of physiologic and pathologic conditions.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70onv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b76ft","text":"Steps","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e53qe","text":"Enrichment of circRNAs for generation of Nanopore sequencing libraries","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":70}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvd6o","text":"1. This is an important step for the final enrichment of circRNAs. The ribodepletion follows the published protocol from Baldwin et al. 2021 with some modifications, which uses a pool of 195 DNA oligonucleotides directed against human rRNAs. DNA:RNA duplexes get digested by RNaseH and remaining DNA oligos will be digested by DNase. We multiplex usually 4 samples that can be treated in parallel throughout the workflow.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5r1g0","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"btlt5","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"authors":"Baldwin A, Morris AR, Mukherjee N","can_edit":1,"date":"1622505600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1002/cpz1.176","guid":"409B7E00748411ECB7C82BCAB2D4C7C4","id":1474,"journal":"Current protocols","protocol_id":"0","title":"An Easy, Cost-Effective, and Scalable Method to Deplete Human Ribosomal RNA for RNA-seq."},"mutability":"","type":"citation"}}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b0kuh","text":"It is recommended to also do an untreated Mock control through the protocol that will be used for the comparison of circRNA enrichment in the section quality control.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2mq6i","text":"Calculation of the library's molarity","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c37im","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1at2e","text":"Calculate the amount of fmol in your sample by using the results of the quantification and library size determination. This can be done by using e.g. the Biomath Calculator from Promega (Link to Promega Biomath calculatores) using the calculator DNA: µg to pmol. The recommended input for Oxford Nanopore library preparation with the kit SQK-LSK109 is 1 µg (or 100-200 fmol) of PCR amplicons. Since the circRNA abundance is still relatively low, multiplexing of several libraries with the native barcoding kit (EXP-NBD104) is recommended to occupy enough pores.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":187,"length":36}],"data":{}},{"key":"f9gir","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8gm3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4h3nj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"CF1081C49C9011ECBA140A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://france.promega.com/resources/tools/biomath"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bjcjn","text":"The input recommendation of the Oxford Nanopore library protocol EXP-NBD104 and SQK-LSK109 is 100-200 fmol for each library that will be pooled. circRNAs","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7at3","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":15,"offset":468},{"key":1,"length":14,"offset":504},{"key":2,"length":17,"offset":549}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3oe4j","text":"To specifically amplify the backsplice-junction of circRNAs and not the cognate linear RNAs transcribed from the same gene, divergent (outward-facing) primer pairs have to be designed that will only lead to a PCR product if the template is circular. It is preferable to have one primer spanning the backsplice-junction to increase specificity, which is especially important when several isoforms of a circRNA exist. Common tools to design circRNA-specific primers are CircInteractome (Dudekula, 2016) or CircPrimer 2.0 (Zhong, 2022). Alternatively, NCBI Primer-BLAST can be used manually by taking the sequence of the backsplice-junction (ca. 100 nt upstream and downstream) and inverting the order of the exons forming the junction.","type":"align-justify"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"056079D0F21011EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","url":"https://circinteractome.nia.nih.gov/index.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"1":{"data":{"guid":"12F075F0F21011EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","url":"https://www.bio-inf.cn"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"2":{"data":{"guid":"1CFB6A00F21011EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/primer-blast/"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Dudekula DB, Panda AC, Grammatikakis I, De S, Abdelmohsen K, Gorospe M","can_edit":1,"date":"1451606400","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1080/15476286.2015.1128065","guid":"3A6D6890F21011EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","id":1834,"journal":"RNA biology","protocol_id":"0","title":"CircInteractome: A web tool for exploring circular RNAs and their interacting proteins and microRNAs."}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Zhong S, Feng J","can_edit":1,"date":"1654473600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1186/s12859-022-04705-y","guid":"486DD9C0F21011EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","id":1835,"journal":"BMC bioinformatics","protocol_id":"0","title":"CircPrimer 2.0: a software for annotating circRNAs and predicting translation potential of circRNAs."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8u3qq","text":"Expected Results, limitations and troubleshooting","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":49},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":49}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8qr3n","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2191t","text":"Expected results and interpretation","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":35},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2p2gp","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4280g","text":"Using our protocol libraries of an average length of 606.75 nt and a concentration of 5 ng/µl, thus almost 150 ng in total can be generated (Fig. 2, Tab. 2). This will be enough for several rounds of sequencing, if a high number of reads is needed to also detect lower expressed circRNAs. The library length is about the average published size of circRNAs, which is reported to be between 200 - 800 nt (Guo, 2014; Zheng, 2019) and shows that our workflow does not fragment RNA and maintains its size. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb63d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"99afu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ilqs","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"18bds","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5d4do","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep7aq","text":" SU-DHL-1 Karpas COST SUP-M2 Average Concentration [ng/µl] 5.12 4.68 4.92 4.5 4.81 Size [nt] 654 629 573 571 606.8 ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":272}],"data":{}},{"key":"1mb6u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"68ebo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vcm2","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j7rd","text":" ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43eua","text":"Figure 2: Generated libraries have the size of the average circRNA length. Shown is the library created from RNA of the anaplastic large-cell lymphoma cell lineSU-DHL-1. The library size was analyzed by Fragment Analyzer with the kit hs NGS. The average library size was 654 nt. RFU, relative fluorescence units.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":75}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fis1i","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmbrm","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65tk6","text":"Unwanted RNA transcripts should get depleted and the depletion is tested by qRT-PCR. Ribosomal RNA, as indicated by 18S rRNA, gets usually depleted more than 5 Cts, we achieve regularly a depletion of around 10 Ct. Further, mitochondrial RNA (as indicated by mtRNR1), small-nucleolar RNA (as indicated by RNU6B) and the RNA component of the signal recognition particle (as indicated by RN7SL2), which can be very abundant, should be depleted > 5 cycles. circRNAs should be stable or enriched, and cognate linear RNAs should get depleted (Fig. 3).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10rh","text":" ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eousf","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9a581","text":" ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"120rh","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5s92n","text":"Using the ligation-based sequencing kit (SQK-LSK109) together with the native barcoding kit (EXP-NBD104) 4 libraries of 4 different human anaplastic large-cell lymphoma cell lines (SU-DHL-1, Karpas-299, COST, SUP-M2) were pooled together and the pool was sequenced on a MinION (MK1C, Oxford Nanopore). The sequencing output was on average 1,536,242 reads per library and reads were of high quality (Tab. 3, mean Q-score 15).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"frc55","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8r8kk","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2m3ma","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cma24","text":" SU-DHL1 Karpas COST SUP-M2 Average Raw reads 1,473,419 1,734,196 899,725 2,037,577 1,536,229 Mean read length [nt] 459.6 368.2 386.3 403.3 404.4 Maximum read length [nt] 4,006 3,889 3,538 3,455 3,722 BSJ-reads (% of reads) 1.05 0.95 0.95 1.06 1.00 Full-length circRNAs 15,673 16,725 8,750 21,918 15,767 Different circRNAs 3,143 3,195 1,426 4,017 2,945 Mean circRNA length [nt] 435.1 354.9 366.4 370.4 381.7 Maximum circRNA length [nt] 1,798 1,634 1,596 2,228 1,814 ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":934}],"data":{}},{"key":"fgtc1","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9v7lh","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5s6lo","text":"The run took on average 40 h. Of note, the pores were not completely saturated, so probably a longer sequencing run with higher output would have been possible. Following the analysis workflow described for CIRI-Long we could identify on average 15,767 circRNA-specific reads, thus 1.0 % of the total reads, similar to the study from Zhang et al., of which 99 % covered the full length of the circRNA. For most of them, concatamers were detected and, as expected, several isoforms were identified and reported by CIRI-Long. On average 2,945 different circRNAs were identified. We noticed that the more reads are generated, more different full-length circRNA isoforms are detected, which could be another argument for deeper sequencing. The results were comparable among the samples from the 4 different cell lines, showing the robustness of the workflow. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":340,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36g1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cjtj0","text":"In summary, this modified protocol facilitates consistent full-length sequencing of circRNAs, which will help to study this noncoding RNA type in a variety of physiologic and pathologic contexts.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3q448","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2j0e","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"en5u4","text":"Enrichment of circRNAs for generation of Nanopore sequencing libraries","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":70},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":70}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0go7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4i285","text":"This section provides the detailed protocol to enrich the fraction of circRNAs that will be used to create sequencing libraries for the Nanopore platform.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"flhd","text":"Suggestions for Nanopore sequencing and data analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"465dh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6cmt","text":"This section provides links to the used Nanopore sequencing protocols with further information and improvements, and suggestions for the bioinformatics analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dc0k7","text":"Protocols for Oxford Nanopore sequencing:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":41},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":41}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1alub","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89ftu","text":"Protocols are available from the Nanopore community (free login required): ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":33,"length":18}],"data":{}},{"key":"fa0rp","text":"The following protocol was used according to the manufacturer:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"55nn1","text":"Native barcoding amplicons (with EXP-NBD104, EXP-NBD114, and SQK-LSK109) v12Nov2019","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":83}],"data":{}},{"key":"cj3ms","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkt5c","text":"We included small modifications that we will describe below together with the general steps of the library preparation. We use an Oxford Nanopore MinION MK1C sequencer that includes a graphical card needed for base calling of the raw Nanopore sequencing data (.fast5 format) to generate .fastq files that are needed for further analysis. A standard MinION can be used as well and base calling can be performed afterwards with a computer and the Nanopore MinKNOW software.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B8DECD61F22011ECA31A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://nanoporetech.com/community"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B8DECDACF22011ECA31A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://community.nanoporetech.com/docs/prepare/library_prep_protocols/native-barcoding-amplicons/v/nba_9093_v109_revj_12nov2019?devices=minion"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dob7p","text":"1) End-preparation: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aa4p1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qsvj","text":"This step prepares the DNA ends for adapter attachment. The manufacturer recommends 100-200 fmol of RNA input. We use up to 1000 fmol, to have enough material for several rounds of sequencing. Our circRNA-enrichment workflow provides enough output to achieve this.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"puo0","text":"2) Native barcode ligation and pooling:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"duc9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pbca","text":"Nanopore barcodes will be attached to the ends of the DNA in this step. The manufacturer recommends to use 100-200 fmol of end-prepped DNA. Here, we used 22.5 µl of the reaction from step 1). The samples are cleaned-up with magnetic beads and eluted. The manufacturer recommends a high elution volume, which would make a concentration step necessary whenmultiplexing various samples. To avoid this, we elute only in 11 µl, to obtain 10 µl of sample for the pooling and 1 µl to measure the concentration (see below). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6jvo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehgta","text":"For the pooling, we measure the concentration of the sampleswith a Qubit fluorometer (BR dsDNA assay) and calculate the molarity as described above. Expected recovery aim 15-25 ng/µl (molarity 30-70 fmol/µl). Equimolar amounts of samples should be pooled. The protocol recommends 100-200 fmol, we usually use 400 fmol per sample and pool 4-5 samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cit80","text":"3) Adapter ligation and clean-up","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fop9","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7kn1k","text":"This step attaches the Nanopore sequencing adapters. After adding the adapters a clean-up is performed with magnetic beads. The manufacturer uses a ratio of 0.5x beads to sample to select for long fragments \u003e500 nt. However, we use a ratio of 0.8x to include as well fragments of \u003e200nt, since the expected size of circRNAs is 200-800 nt (Guo, 2014; Zheng, 2019). This also is the reason why the short fragment buffer has to be used for the clean-up. We perform in total 3 washes with the short fragment buffer to eliminate chemical components that might potentially interfere with sequencing (only 2 are recommended in the official protocol). The cleaned-up sequencing pool is measured with a Qubit fluorometer (BR dsDNA assay). Recovery aim: 30-50 ng/µl (ca. 50-90 fmol/µl). To calculate the molarity, we use the average length (as measured in the QC section by Fragment Analyzer) of all samples pooled. The final library pool is ready for sequencing and should be stored for short-term at 4 °C until the sequencing run is finished for possible flushing of the flow cell and reloading of the library (see below).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cjv00","text":"4) Priming and loading the flow cell","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":36}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pknm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lha1","text":"Finally the flow cell is primed and the library loaded. Please note that the pores in the flow cell needed for sequencing are not very stable and the number of active pores correlates with the sequencing output. Care has to be taken to keep as much pores active for sequencing as possible. For instance, air bubbles that get introduced by pipetting during the priming process can irreversibly damage them. Further, during priming the storage buffer that keeps the pores stable is taken off. The manufacturer recommends to wait 5 min. until the library gets loaded. In our experience it is best to prepare the library mix before starting the priming process so that the pores are as short as possible without the storage buffer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2gimh","text":"The recommendation of the manufacturer is to load 5-50 fmol. In our experience this can be increased to 200 fmol. Of note, this does still not fully saturate the pores.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bos2j","text":"Sequencing is started on the MK1C with the base calling option activated using standard settings. We further activate also demultiplexing (standard settings), to directly separate the reads in the respective samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8v2me","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dfjn9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fdh4l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":83,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"1cqb6","text":"Optional: washing the flow cell and reloading the library during the sequencing run","type":"align-justify"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3p6re","text":"","type":"align-justify"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":64,"offset":304}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7ambg","text":"The pores get inactive over time, which is a normal process. However, when sequencing short fragments this process is much faster. We observe after 1d a significant number of inactive pores (unavailable state in the MinKNOW view). We recommend to perform then a nuclease flush of the flow cell using the Flow Cell Wash Kit (EXP-WSH004, Nanopore community login needed) according to the manufacturer. This will take off the library and helps to recover pores, in our experience around 10-20 %. We then perform another flow cell priming as described before und re-load the library pool (200-300 fmol). With this approach the usually obtained 8-10 million reads can be increased to up to 15 million reads.","type":"align-justify"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"CC78E3C0F22111EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","url":"http://(https://community.nanoporetech.com/docs/prepare/library_prep_protocols/flow-cell-wash-kit-exp-wsh004/v/wfc_9120_v1_revd_08dec2020"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

steps.section: 6) Recommendations for bioinformatics analysis of the data
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9o1co","text":"Bioinformatics analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5kaul","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bt8j6","text":"Demultiplexing and base calling of raw data were realized by using the Guppy toolkit from the MinKNOW software (v22.05.8) using standard parameters as described above. This creates .fastq files from the raw .fast5 data. Only passed .fastq files assigned to samples were used for next analyses. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8o3dh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qf7b","text":"Analysis of the base-called sequencing data in fastq format involves the following steps:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6jund","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dff9m","text":"•\tCleaning the reads from the adapters with cutadapt v3.4","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"binr7","text":"•\tIdentifying circRNAs by using the CIRI-Long tool v1.0.3","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arerl","text":"•\tCreating alignments with minimap2 v2.19 and visualize circRNA-spanning reads in IGV Genomics Viewer v2.9.4.     ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ace5e","text":"        The used genome annotation was GRCh38. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: 6) Recommendations for bioinformatics analysis of the data
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b0qc4","text":"Cleaning the reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lv2e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2i1m4","text":"Cleaning the reads was done with cutadapt v3.4 and removes the adapter sequences. The following settings were used for the analysis:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":33,"length":13}],"data":{}},{"key":"f5d03","text":"-\tSelect reads with non-zero length (-m 1) and set less than 20 % error rate (-e 0.2)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfflp","text":"-\tCommand lines to clean the reads with the used adapter sequences:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clsmc","text":"cutadapt -e 0.2 -m 1 -g AAGCAGTGGTATCAACGCAGAGTAC -o FileName_5pTrimmed.fastq.gz FileName.fastq.gz","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"foga2","text":"cutadapt -e 0.2 -m 1 -a GTACTCTGCGTTGATACCACTGCTT -o TrimmedFileName.fastq.gz FileName_5pTrimmed.fastq.gz","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hjl7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"724h4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D1951120F22211EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","url":"https://github.com/marcelm/cutadapt"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":67,"offset":182},{"key":1,"length":36,"offset":256}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":90,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2feue","text":"MARTIN, Marcel. Cutadapt removes adapter sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads. EMBnet.journal, [S.l.], v. 17, n. 1, p. pp. 10-12, may 2011. ISSN 2226-6089. Available at: \u003chttps://journal.embnet.org/index.php/embnetjournal/article/view/200\u003e. doi:https://doi.org/10.14806/ej.17.1.200\n","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"2B1F7868F22311ECA31A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://journal.embnet.org/index.php/embnetjournal/article/view/200"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"1":{"data":{"guid":"2B1F78A1F22311ECA31A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://doi.org/10.14806/ej.17.1.200"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

steps.section: 6) Recommendations for bioinformatics analysis of the data
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9a42e","text":"Identifying circRNAs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1icc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8spi8","text":"We used the CIRI-long software (v1.0.3; Zhang, 2021) with default parameters to identify circRNAs. CIRI-long first splits reads produced by rolling circle amplification into repetitive fragments by searching for identical repeated sequences. This first step allows to detect the boundaries of circRNAs which are then aligned against the genome to generate a consensus sequence. It uses splice sites from known exon annotations and canonical de novo GT/AG splice signals to align junction sites but also non-canonical splice signals when canonical signals are not present. Of note, a bwa index is required for the reference genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e02po","text":"Only passed reads, not considered unclassified, were used for the analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3chjs","text":"-\tCommand lines used:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvsq7","text":"CIRI-long call -i FileName.fastq.gz -o step1 -r genome.fa -p SampleName -a genome.gtf -t 10","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fqf2","text":"CIRI-long collapse -i SampleFile.lst -o step2 -p SampleName -r genome.fa -a genome.gtf -t 10","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nj2o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6f0si","text":"CIRI-long will create several output files with the distinct circRNA isoforms detected and the number of reads in the different samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nk7c","text":"In step1, it provides fasta files of reads predicted as circRNA with related information on, for example, the size and genomic coordinates of the circRNA, and the identified splice signal. Isoforms from all samples are collapsed in step2. The main outputs are an expression matrix providing collapsed isoforms counting and a gtf-like file that contains detailed information of circRNAs and annotation of circRNA back-spliced regions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d26e3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e07n0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Zhang J, Hou L, Zuo Z, Ji P, Zhang X, Xue Y, Zhao F","can_edit":1,"date":"1625097600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1038/s41587-021-00842-6","guid":"1F87CA20F22411EC9D168B8EC5048AC3","id":1836,"journal":"Nature biotechnology","protocol_id":"0","title":"Comprehensive profiling of circular RNAs with nanopore sequencing and CIRI-long."}}}}

steps.section: 6) Recommendations for bioinformatics analysis of the data
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b62rn","text":"Alignments to visualize circRNA-spanning reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"at6nj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8epik","text":"CIRI-Long involves an alignment step, but the bam files containing the aligned reads are not conserved.  Therefore, we created separate alignments, by aligning long reads against the human genome (GRCh38) using the minimap2  software (v2.19, Li, 2018), converted in bam format by using samtools  (v1.12, Li, 2009) and visualized using IGV Genomics Viewer (v2.9.4, Robinson, 2011) keeping supplementary alignments, which allows to visualize inverted segments. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gn37","text":"- Command lines used:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76etk","text":"minimap2 -ax splice -t 20 -uf -k14 genome_index FileName.fastq.gz \u003e FileName.sam ; samtools view -b FileName.sam|samtools sort \u003e FileName.bam ; samtools index FileName.bam).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b48ik","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"4o1b0","text":"Limitations and challenges","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31vj1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5cip","text":"A limitation of the protocol is the relatively high input of RNA of 7 µg. While this amount of RNA worked best in our experiments, we also tried successfully only 3-5 µg. Further, in general the Nanopore sequencing platform produces less reads than Illumina-based short read techniques, especially when using the MinION. That means lowly abundant circRNAs might not be detected by our sequencing protocol. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5kse5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9skkg","text":"Limitations of CIRI-Long are that the alignment parameters cannot be modified and bam files containing the aligned reads are not conserved. Further, there is no option to detect fusion circRNAs derived from fusion genes (distant genes, genes located on different chromosomes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cm6ab","text":"Troubleshooting","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bf8fu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3bb5k","text":"Below we provide assistance and recommendations for problems that can occur during this protocol and the analysis of the data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bjhlr","text":"circRNA enrichment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5uc34","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9veaq","text":"Step 7 RNaseR treatment: if the enrichment of circRNAs seems to be insufficient, a longer incubation with RNaseR could be tried.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7vsru","text":"Step 11 PCR amplification: if the obtained amount of cDNA is much lower than expected, the volume of the PCR reaction and/or the amount of PCR cycles could be increased.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddj4b","text":"Step 12 Fragment size selection: if the size of the circRNAs of interest that should be enriched is much higher or lower, the ratio of beads to DNA could be adapted. A higher ratio will lead to retention of smaller fragments, a lower ratio will select for longer fragments.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dcbf4","text":"Validation of circRNA enrichment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37o4p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejg8s","text":"While we provide a selection of primers covering different RNA species that should be depleted by the workflow, further transcripts can be checked by qRT-PCR in this step. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"76ies","text":"Nanopore sequencing","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20jp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36ab0","text":"Care has to be taken to not introduce air bubbles while priming or loading a flow cell, since this will damage pores irreversibly.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ck9qd","text":"The pore activity should be closely monitored while sequencing. If a lot of inactive pores accumulate, a flow cell wash could be performed as described above.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aarm2","text":"If a lot of pores are available, but not occupied, more library could be loaded. If the translocation speed is \u003e 300, then no further priming is usually needed.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f8438","text":"Bioinformatics analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqlrg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5iarg","text":"Alignments were re-generated using minimap2 (v2.19, GRCh38) and visualized in IGV Genomics Viewer (v2.9.4) to validate the presence of concatamers. Linking supplementary alignments also helped to visualize circularization junctions.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efhqk","text":"To detect fusion circRNAs sam files produced by minimap2 during the alignment can be filtered to conserve chimeric alignments that contain segments of the same read aligning to distant genes (on the same or different chromosomes). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
